articles.headline: With Alex Jones, Facebook’s Worst Demons Abroad Begin to Come Home
articles.snippet: The social network’s links to violence and unrest may not be exclusive to developing countries like India or Myanmar, as some once argued.
articles.abstract: The social network’s links to violence and unrest may not be exclusive to developing countries like India or Myanmar, as some once argued.
articles.lead_paragraph: To Americans, Facebook’s Alex Jones problem might seem novel, even unprecedented.

articles.headline: U.S. to Issue New Sanctions on Russia Over Skripals’ Poisoning
articles.snippet: The sanctions are part of anti-Russian efforts by the United States, even as President Trump works to forge warmer ties.
articles.abstract: The sanctions are part of anti-Russian efforts by the United States, even as President Trump works to forge warmer ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said on Wednesday that it would soon impose new sanctions against Russia in response to the attempted assassination in March of a former Russian spy living in England and his daughter.

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Pitch to Take Tesla Private Has Wall Street Salivating
articles.snippet: Banks including Citigroup and Goldman Sachs are looking at ways to structure transactions for Tesla that would remove the automaker from the public markets.
articles.abstract: Banks including Citigroup and Goldman Sachs are looking at ways to structure transactions for Tesla that would remove the automaker from the public markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after Elon Musk declared that he might try to convert Tesla into a private company, Wall Street banks raced to figure out how such a transaction might work and how they might get a piece of the action.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Peter Eavis and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Manafort’s Judge, T.S. Ellis, Is a ‘Caesar’ in His Own Rome
articles.snippet: The message Judge T.S. Ellis III gives lawyers in his court is clear: Keep questions on point, move briskly and show some respect.
articles.abstract: The message Judge T.S. Ellis III gives lawyers in his court is clear: Keep questions on point, move briskly and show some respect.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: Paul Manafort was sentenced to 47 months in prison on Thursday in this financial fraud case. Read the article here.]
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Trump’s Tariffs on Canadian Newsprint Hasten Local Newspapers’ Demise
articles.snippet: Surging newsprint costs are adding to the woes of struggling local newspapers, forcing them to reduce staff and publication days.
articles.abstract: Surging newsprint costs are adding to the woes of struggling local newspapers, forcing them to reduce staff and publication days.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s decision to impose tariffs on Canadian newsprint is hastening the demise of local newspapers across the country, forcing already-struggling publications to cut staff, reduce the number of days they print and, in at least one case, shutter entirely.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson and Jaclyn Peiser

articles.headline: Tribune Ends Deal With Sinclair, Dashing Plan for Conservative TV Behemoth
articles.snippet: The announcement definitively ends efforts by the Sinclair Broadcast Group to create a broadcast giant and potential rival to Rupert Murdoch’s Fox News.
articles.abstract: The announcement definitively ends efforts by the Sinclair Broadcast Group to create a broadcast giant and potential rival to Rupert Murdoch’s Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump cheered when Sinclair Broadcast Group, the nation’s largest operator of local TV stations and a leading voice for conservative views, made a $3.9 billion bid to buy Tribune Media. The consolidation would have created a company that could reach seven out of 10 American households.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Amie Tsang
